attributes.title: GOTV via SMS: One vs. Two Text Messages Election Day Voting Experiment

q1.value: GOTV via SMS: One vs. Two Text Messages Election Day Voting Experiment

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: This field experiment examines SMS text messages as a method of voter mobilization. This experiment tests whether text messages sent to registered voters encouraging voting can increase voter turnout in the 2018 midterm elections. Despite widespread use, SMS messages have received little scholarly attention as a medium for campaign communication (Dale and Strauss 2009; Malhotra et al 2011; Bhatti et al 2017b). This experiment is part of a series of experiments in the 2018 general election to build on this prior research. The experiment compares a single text message treatment, a two text message treatment and a uncontacted control group. The treatment relies on primarily on information about when and where to vote on Election Day to increase turnout. This tactic is very common in voter mobilization and have been successful in past randomized controlled tests (see Green and Gerber 2015 for review). The research question is the impact of multiple text messages vs. a single text message.

attributes.title: The psychology of political risk: Replication and extension

q1.value: The psychology of political risk: Replication and extension

q5.value: Thanks to Graeme Blair, Christopher Blattman, Alexander Coppock, Macartan Humphreys, Albert Fang, Grant Gordon, Donald Green, Isabela Mares, Tamar Mitts, Suresh Naidu, and Gabriella Sacramone-Lutz.

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: This project aims to provide a micro-empirical test of the potential psychological effects of political repression. The threat of political violence is often analyzed as an informational shock to the perceived probability of punishment. However, a large body of research on perceptions of risks suggest that affect has a large effect on how risks are perceived. This study applies this literature to understanding the effects of political violence, particularly violence intended to suppress opposition in an electoral autocracy. This study builds on an earlier experiment pre-registered and carried out in May 2015. It modifies the emotion induction technique and measurement of covariates, aims to replicate the original outcome measures, and adds additional outcomes.The two studies will be presented together in a paper discussing the results of both.

q16.value: Subjects who receive the fear treatments will be more pessimistic in their assessments of political risks. Subjects who receive the fear treatments will believe that fewer of their fellow opposition supporters will take pro-opposition actions. Subjects who receive the fear treatments will be less willing to take pro-opposition political actions. Subjects who receive the fear treatments will be more pessimistic in their assessments of economic risks. Subjects who receive the fear treatments will be more risk averse in financial decisions. The effect of the political and general fear treatments will be equal.

q17.value: Hypotheses will be tested with multivariate analysis that includes controls for the community, gender, an assets index, age, and education. I will also present difference-in-means tests. The main results will come from the pooled sample of people assigned to the political and apolitical emotion conditions. I will also test for differences across the political and general treatment conditions but do not expect that these effects will differ. If they are significantly different, then I will run the analysis separately for political and general emotions and discuss the results separately.

attributes.title: Migration, Magic, and the Risk of Dying: Evidence from Real-Time Migration Decisions in The Gambia

q1.value: Migration, Magic, and the Risk of Dying: Evidence from Real-Time Migration Decisions in The Gambia

q2.value: Daniel Auer | Johanna Gereke | Max Schaub

q5.value: We thank Hanno Hilbig and Remi Colley for their valuable comments on this study's design.

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: Beliefs in magic and superstitions have been observed to influence a range of outcomes, including warfare, business and electoral choice (Tsang 2004; Nunn and Sanchez de la Sierra 2017; Hirshleifer et al 2016). In the context of migration, previous studies have documented the ubiquity of superstitious beliefs in influencing when, where and how aspiring migrants decide to undertake their journeys abroad (Bastide 2015, Hagan 2008, Levitt 2003). For example, Hagan, and Ebaugh (2003) describe the role of pentecostal pastors in Guatemala as migration "advisors," while religious guides - "marabouts" - in Senegal provide migrants with a range of services, from spiritual protection, to suggesting appropriate departure dates, to scanning passenger lists for problematic individuals with whom contact should be avoided (Hernández-Carretero and Carling 2012). Similarly, in his ethnography of Mexican farmworkers in California's Central Valley, Holmes (2013, p.1) notes that, amongst the few items migrants carry with them on their desert crossing into the US, is usually "a plastic bag with coyote fur and pine sap [called a 'suerte', meaning 'luck'] made by a Triqui healer for protection." However, most of the existing research on superstition and migration stems from qualitative interviews and anecdotal evidence from migrants' life histories. Building on these findings, this study empirically investigates whether magical and superstitious beliefs influence the decision to migrate using an original longitudinal data set. We do so in the context of The Gambia, which has seen some of the highest migration rates in the world in recent years. Most migrants from The Gambia aim to reach Europe - an endeavour that is exceptionally risky. It is estimated that up to 20% of individuals who set out on the journey perish along the way (e.g., Camara and Huntö 2018). The country also is a context where beliefs in magic are common. We hypothesize that magical beliefs make individuals likely to underestimate the risk of the migratory journey, and make them more trusting of smugglers, who often betray this trust. In order to test these hypotheses, we ask 10,000 potential migrants who will be re-interviewed several times during a 9-months period. This will allow us to observe actual migration decisions, and to link these to beliefs in magic, risk attitudes and trust perceptions.

q16.value: One possible explanation linking risky migration decisions to magic relates to the fact that individuals often underestimate negative outcomes (and overestimate positive ones) if they relate to themselves vis-à-vis to a general or more objective assessment of the situation. That is, migrants may be overconfident about their exposure to life-threatening situations en route, and may underestimate their risk of dying relative to others. We argue that superstitions, fatalism, and the usage of ``magic'' such as lucky charms and protection spells, function as a driver of such overconfidence. Hence, we define overconfidence twofold: as the absolute perception of the risk of dying, and as the difference of the respondent's perception between the individual and the general risk of dying. Overconfidence assumption: Magic beliefs are related to lower perceptions of individual risk. Another possible explanation is that magic rituals make individuals unwarranted trusting in smugglers and other facilitators of their migration journey. Such facilitators are known to often betray and exploit their customers, sometimes putting them in mortal danger. Trust assumption: Magic beliefs are related to individuals' to trust in migration facilitators.

q17.value: Overall, overconfidence and trust, both driven by superstitions or ``magic'' lead to higher migration propensities: H1 – migration: Magic beliefs predict subsequent migration. Accordingly, we test three models where individual over-confidence Y_c, trust Y_b, and migration behaviour Y_m: Y_(i,c,b,m)=b_i τ+X_it δ+ε_it ... where Y_(i,c,b,m) is a function of magic beliefs b_i and a vector of individual socio-economic covariates X_it (including gender, age, family status, networks abroad, earnings, nutrition, appearance, etc.) at time t. To allow for general causal statements about the perceived importance of metaphysical beliefs, we introduce an experiment where respondents are asked for a hypothetical person's survival probability. This hypothetical migrant is a young Gambian man, who - with random variation - is additionally characterised by one of the following traits: religiosity, magic protection, economic capability, expertise, and information (see section 2.1 Experiment). This exogenous variation addresses potential endogeneity bias resulting from superstitious beliefs potentially being related to other drivers of migration. (For instance, better educated respondents may be less likely to belief in protection spells and more likely to be informed about the route, at the same time.)

attributes.title: Emotional Effects of Viewing Academic Instagram Posts
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

question2a.value: Experimental condition (between-groups design): Positive Condition – Academic Achievement, Negative Condition – Academic Non-Achievement, Neutral Condition (control) – Academic Condition

question2b.value:
•	Social comparison emotions (8 from Park & Baek, 2018)
•	Positive/negative affect
•	Academic motivation
•	Manipulation check (positivity and negativity of the Instagram post)

question10b.value: Procedure: participants complete informed consent, demographic form, and measures of social comparison orientation and self-esteem.  They are then randomly assigned to view three Instagram posts in one of three conditions (Positive Condition – Academic Achievement: e.g. Instagram post depicting someone acing all their tests, Negative Condition – Academic Non-Achievement: e.g. an Instagram post depicting someone who failed all their tests, Neutral (control) Condition – Academic): and Instagram post depicting someone studying.  Then participants will complete a manipulation check question, and the 4 dependent variables are then presented in a random order.

question4b.value:
Participants must be: 
1. Over 18 years of age
2. An active (logon at least 3 times per week) user of Instagram
3. Currently enrolled as an undergraduate student at researchers' university

question5b.value: Data will be collected from our university Psychology department’s participant pool via SONA. Our student participants will complete an online survey and their responses will be collected and anonymized.  Participants will receive course credit for participation.

question6b.value: To detect a medium effect size (f = .26) between 3 groups (one-way ANOVA) with alpha set at .05 and power of .80, the number of participants required is approximately N = 150 (50 participants per group).

question7b.value: We will stop collecting data once we have recruited 150 participants (final N after exclusions).

question8b.value:
•	We will remove data from participants who failed the manipulation check (i.e., positive condition: did not indicate either “agree” or “strongly agree” that the Instagram posts were positive, or did not indicate either “strongly disagree” or “disagree” that the posts were negative; neutral condition: indicated either “strongly disagree” or “strongly agree” that the posts were either positive or negative; negative condition: did not indicate “strongly disagree” or “disagree” that the posts were positive, or did not indicate “agree” or “strongly agree” that the posts were negative).
•	We will remove participants who failed the attention check question embedded in the measure of self-esteem.
•	We will remove participants who complete the study in less than 4 minutes or more than 60 minutes.
•	We will remove duplicates, overly consistent responses (e.g., indicating “1” for everything), and cases with more than 10% missing data
•	Will not exclude participants on the basis of any other outlier data

question9b.value: We are not setting any fail-safe levels of exclusion for stopping, altering, or restarting the study.

question8c.value: If an item reduces Cronbach’s alpha to less than .50, it will be deleted from the scale.

question10c.value:
Tolerance/VIF will be examined to see if predictors in multiple regressions show too much multicollinearity. If they do, we will conduct PAF (direct oblimin rotation) to reduce the correlated predictors into a single variable.

We assume that the academic motivation scale is unidimensional, but will conduct an exploratory factor structure (PAF, direct oblimin rotation) to verify. If it is multidimensional, we will treat each factor as a separate DV.

question1a.value:
Hypothesis 1(a): Manipulation check. Participants in the Positive Condition – Academic Achievement should report that the content of the Instagram posts is more positive than participants in the Negative Condition – Academic Non-Achievement and in the Neutral Condition – Academic.

Hypothesis 1(b): Manipulation check. Participants in the Negative Condition – Academic Achievement should report that the content of the Instagram posts is more negative than participants in the Positive Condition – Academic Achievement and in the Neutral Condition – Academic.
Hypothesis 2a: Participants randomly assigned to the Positive Condition – Academic Achievement relative to the Negative Condition – Academic Non-Achievement and Neutral Condition – Academic, will report a) more negative affect, b) less positive affect, c) more upward contrastive social comparison emotions (envy and depression), and d) higher levels of academic motivation.

Hypothesis 2b: Participants randomly assigned to the Negative Condition – Academic Non-Achievement relative to the Positive Condition – Academic Achievement and the Neutral Condition – Academic, will report a) more positive affect, b) less negative affect, c) more downward contrastive emotions (pride and schadenfreude), and d) lower levels of academic motivation.

Hypothesis 3: Experimental condition will interact with social comparison orientation, such that the associations described in Hypotheses 2a and 2b will be stronger for people higher in social comparison orientation relative to people lower in social comparison orientation.

question2a.value: The associations described in Hypotheses 2a and 2b will be stronger for people higher in social comparison orientation relative to people lower in social comparison orientation.

question1c.value: For all of the following analyses, variables will be calculated as mean scores across all of the items included in each scale.

question2c.value:
Hypothesis 1(a): Manipulation check. Participants in the Positive Condition – Academic Achievement should report that the content of the Instagram posts is more positive than participants in the Negative Condition – Academic Non-Achievement and in the Neutral Condition – Academic.

Hypothesis 1(b): Manipulation check. Participants in the Negative Condition – Academic Achievement should report that the content of the Instagram posts is more negative than participants in the Positive Condition – Academic Achievement and in the Neutral Condition – Academic.

The hypothesis will be tested with two one-way ANOVAs. Pairwise comparisons will be conducted with Bonferroni-corrected t-tests.

question3c.value:
Predictors: condition
Covariates: none
DV: positivity and negativity ratings

question1c.value:
For all of the following analyses, variables will be calculated as mean scores across all of the items included in each scale. 

Upward contrastive emotions: envy, depression
Downward contrastive emotions: pride, schadenfreude

question2c.value:
Hypothesis 2a: Participants randomly assigned to the Positive Condition – Academic Achievement relative to the Negative Condition – Academic Non-Achievement and Neutral Condition – Academic, will report a) more negative affect, b) less positive affect, c) more upward contrastive social comparison emotions (envy and depression), and d) higher levels of academic motivation.

Hypothesis 2b: Participants randomly assigned to the Negative Condition – Academic Non-Achievement relative to the Positive Condition – Academic Achievement and the Neutral Condition – Academic, will report a) more positive affect, b) less negative affect, c) more downward contrastive emotions (pride and schadenfreude), and d) lower levels of academic motivation.

Hypothesis 3: Experimental condition will interact with social comparison orientation, such that the associations described in Hypotheses 2a and 2b will be stronger for people higher in social comparison orientation relative to people lower in social comparison orientation.

Hypotheses 2 and 3 will be tested with hierarchical multiple regression analysis (for each of the DVs). The first block will include the two dummy coded variables for condition; the second block with include social comparison orientation, self-esteem, and the interactions of the dummy coded variables with social comparison orientation.

question3c.value:
Predictors: condition; two dummy coded variables (a) Positive Condition (1) vs. Neutral Condition (0); and (b) Negative Condition (1) vs Neutral Condition (0). 
Moderators: social comparison orientation
Covariates: self-esteem
DVs: Upward contrastive emotions, downward contrastive emotions, positive/negative affect, academic motivation

question4c.value: Self-esteem is included as a covariate to ensure that any effects are driven by experimental condition and interactions with social comparison orientation rather than self-esteem.

attributes.title: The Roots of Political Resentment: Racial Resentment from Rural Consciousness

q1.value: The Roots of Political Resentment: Racial Resentment from Rural Consciousness

q5.value: The authors would like to acknowledge Professor Nicholas Valentino of the University of Michigan for providing the idea behind the paper.

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: There is an extensive literature regarding the role of racial resentment in political decision-making/ preferences; see Banks and Valentino (2012), for example. However, Katherine Cramer of the University of Madison, Wisconsin in 2016 wrote a book explaining that for rural residents, place-based preferences are often central to political decision-making. She argues that although racial biases still can and do play a role, that role is much smaller than previously assumed. This experiment, using a 2x3 design, attempts to disentangle racial resentment from rural consciousness by controlling the perception of which parts of a respondent’s state will benefit from a proposed education bond measure while varying the implications of which race will primarily benefit.

q16.value: The main dependent variable is respondent support for the education variable (on a 4-point scale from strongly oppose to strongly support). Also included is a feelings thermometer to capture additional variation. We also measure key moderators, such as racial resentment (using the Kinder and Sanders (1996) battery of questions) and rural consciousness (using a battery of questions developed by Cramer herself). The main hypotheses will revolve around the relative effects of racial resentment and rural consciousness on support for the education bond measure. Please see pre-analysis plan for more detailed hypotheses.

q17.value: Because we are using a population-based survey experiment, we will use t-tests as well as multiple regressions to test the hypotheses. See pre-analysis plan for more detailed methodology.

registration_responses.q15: There is an extensive literature regarding the role of racial resentment in political decision-making/ preferences; see Banks and Valentino (2012), for example. However, Katherine Cramer of the University of Madison, Wisconsin in 2016 wrote a book explaining that for rural residents, place-based preferences are often central to political decision-making. She argues that although racial biases still can and do play a role, that role is much smaller than previously assumed. This experiment, using a 2x3 design, attempts to disentangle racial resentment from rural consciousness by controlling the perception of which parts of a respondent’s state will benefit from a proposed education bond measure while varying the implications of which race will primarily benefit.

attributes.title: Do Debates Matter? The Impact of Parliamentary Debates on Voter Preferences and Attitudes in Ghana

q1.value: Do Debates Matter? The Impact of Parliamentary Debates on Voter Preferences and Attitudes in Ghana

q2.value: Eric Kramon | Sarah Brierley | George Ofosu

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: Candidate debates are currently held in over 60 countries around the world. Increasingly, they are being held in developing countries with financial support from international democracy-promotion organizations on the grounds that they strengthen democracy (NDI 2014)}. In developing democracies, debates have the potential to provide valuable information to citizens on the character and policy positions of politicians. Despite the increasing prevalence of candidate debates, there is almost no causal evidence that assesses the impact of debates on voter preferences and voter attitudes towards democracy, especially outside of the US context. Notable exceptions are Bidwell et al. (2016), who conduct a randomized experiment to measure the effect of parliamentary debates in Sierra Leone, and Platas Izama and Raffler (2016), who conduct an experiment around "meet the candidate" sessions, which are similar in structure to debates, in Uganda. Our project complements and seeks to build upon these studies. This study seeks to help fill this gap. The project involves an opportunity to conduct a field experiment on the effects of parliamentary debates on voter preferences in the run-up to Ghana's general elections on 7th December 2016. The debates are being organized by the Ghana Center for Democratic Development (CDD), a leading civil society organization in Ghana. As we are primarily interested in understanding how and why debates impact voters' political preferences, and we aim to conduct in-depth qualitative research on the campaigns in our study areas, we are working in three constituencies, collecting a range of detailed descriptive and experimental data from a sample of roughly 2,000 citizens. The study has two broad objectives: 1) to study the impact of debates on voters' evaluations of candidates and their attitudes towards democracy; and 2) to study the impact of debates on the downstream performance of elected candidates during their terms in office. This pre-analysis plan focuses on the first goal. This project is being funded by the International Growth Centre (IGC) and APSA Centennial Center. The study has IRB approval from George Washington University and UCLA.

q16.value: H1: Debates have a positive effect on voters' evaluations of candidates who participate in the debates. H2: Debates have a larger positive effect on evaluations of non-incumbent/minor candidates. H3: Debates have a larger positive effect on evaluations of candidates who performed well in the debate. H4: Debates have a larger positive effect on evaluations for debate winner among independent and weak partisans. H5: Debates have a stronger positive effect on evaluations of co-partisan candidates for strong partisans. H6: Debates have a stronger positive effect on evaluations of debate winner among politically less informed voters. H7: Debates influence voters because they provide information about candidates' policy positions. H8: Debates influence voters because they provide information about candidates' personal quality -- qualifications, experience, and personality. H9a: Debates influence voters because they provide information about candidates' local policies and programs. H9b: Debates influence voters because they provide information about candidates' national policies and programs. H10: Debates influence voters because of non-verbal (visual) signals and communication. H11: Voters who view debates are more tolerant and trusting of political opponents. H12: Voters who view debates are more likely to reject clientelistic politics. H13: Voters who view debates are more likely have positive perceptions of the efficacy of the election and the legitimacy of the election outcome.

q17.value: We conduct the study in three Ghanaian constituencies. In each constituency, we worked with our partner organization to record the parliamentary debates that took place in that constituency. We sample electoral areas within constituencies (stratifying on electoral competition) to serve as sampling locations for the study. Within electoral areas, individual participants are randomly sampled. Individual participants will be randomly assigned to a debate treatment or a control (placebo) condition. In order to test mechanisms, we "unbundle" the debate treatment, which will allow us to experimentally test hypotheses about the potential mechanisms linking debates to outcomes. To do so, we divide the debates into two segments. The first segment, segment A, will focus on candidate background and qualifications. The debate moderator will ask each candidate to describe their personal background, qualifications, and values. This segment will thus allow candidates to discuss the characteristics that they believe make them high quality candidates and to convey to voters information about their personality and character. The second segment, segment B, will focus on the candidates policy and programmatic positions. The debate moderator will ask each candidate to discuss their positions on two salient policy areas: education and unemployment. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of five experimental conditions. The unit of randomization is at the level of the individual participant. The conditions are: Segment A (candidate image), Segment B (policy), Segment A+B (video), Segment A+B (audio), Control. We measure outcomes with a post-treatment survey, as well as with two behavioral measures of political tolerance and the rejection of clientelism. The behavioral measures involve the mailing of postcards with anti-violence and anti-vote buying messages to our partner organization, the Center for Democratic Development.

attributes.title: Voter Distrust and the Resonance of Party Outsiders in Primary Elections

q1.value: Voter Distrust and the Resonance of Party Outsiders in Primary Elections

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: The bounded rationality of the American voter is well documented. Heuristics like differentiation between the parties represent one solution for how citizens make complex decisions without full information, but in primary elections, when all candidates are running under the same party label, no such heuristic exists. Which heuristics, then, do voters utilize when making decisions in primary elections? This survey experiment will utilize a conjoint analysis design to estimate the marginal effects of five factors which the literature suggests can influence voting decisions in primaries: gender, strategic general election considerations, ideology, party endorsements, and previous political experience. Prior to presenting respondents with profiles of two candidates running in a hypothetical open-seat U.S. House election, we will ask questions designed to measure the respondent’s attitudes toward both government and party institutions. We hypothesize that respondents who are less trusting of those institutions will be less likely to choose the more “establishment”-style candidate. While some scholars have pointed to voters’ risk tolerance to explain support for outsider candidates (Kam and Simas 2012), this study will build on the preliminary work of Dyck, Pearson-Merkowitz, and Coates (2018) to assess the effect of distrust toward government and party institutions on support for party outsiders.

q16.value: H1: Voters who indicate less trust toward government institutions and/or their own parties in part one of the survey will be more likely to support candidates who have the traits of an outsider in part two. H2: Democratic respondents will exhibit more trust in institutions and be more supportive of establishment-style candidates than Republicans. Alternative hypotheses: We will test four alternative theories for voters’ decisions in primary elections. First, some scholars argue that gender shapes perceptions of ideology and candidate quality. On this view, we might expect Democrats to be more supportive of women regardless of their trust in government, while Republicans would be less supportive of women regardless of trust. Second, we will randomize whether or not the House district is likely to be competitive in the general election. Perhaps voters value quality and electability indicators like endorsements, ideology, and political experience to a greater extent if they want to maximize the chance of winning the seat in the general election. Third, perhaps voters who turn out to vote in primary elections (especially open seat races) seek to elect the most liberal or the most conservative candidate possible, regardless of their feelings towards institutions. Fourth scholars of political parties have argued that in low-information elections, endorsements from party elites can serve as a quality signal for voters. On this view, voters should be more likely to support a candidate if they see that their party’s congressional committee or a high-ranking elected official has endorsed that candidate.

q17.value: After collecting demographic information, we will gauge subjects’ trust in government and party institutions by asking how often they trust the following to represent the public’s best interests: Congress, the Supreme Court, the federal government, the president, Republican Party leaders, Democratic Party leaders, etc. Subjects will then indicate their preferences for candidates in hypothetical U.S. House primary elections for the party matching their reported party identification. Following a conjoint analysis design, candidate attributes will vary randomly across age, gender, race, district competitiveness, occupation, previous political experience, ideology, and endorsements. Subjects will each review five candidate pairings. We will estimate the average marginal component effect of each of these causal quantities of interest in order to test our hypotheses. We will also perform subgroup analyses among high- and low-trust respondents and among Democratic and Republican respondents.

attributes.title: Effect of swearing on strength and power performance - a follow up study

q1.value: Effect of swearing on strength and power performance – a follow up study

q3.value:
We have previously shown that repeating a swear word can improve performance of anaerobic and isometric exercise compared with a control condition of repeating a neutral word (Stephens, Spierer and Katehis, in submission). However, the mechanism of effect was unclear because anticipated signs of autonomic arousal in the swearing conditions were not present. The present study aims to further investigate in this area by (i) extending investigation of the range of physical tasks that may be improved by swearing to endurance tasks; (ii) re-appraising autonomic arousal in the context of swearing and physical performance; and (iii) assessing other potential mechanisms, specifically, pain and psychological flow. 

1.	Does repeating a swear word improve performance of physical endurance tasks?
2.	Mechanism#1 Does repeating a swear word in the context of physical endurance produce increases in autonomic arousal relative to repeating a neutral word?
3.	Mechanism#2 Does repeating a swear word in the context of physical endurance produce reduced feelings of pain associated with the exercise relative to repeating a neutral word?
4.	Mechanism#3 Does swearing increase feelings of flow during the physical endurance tasks relative to repeating a neutral word?

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value: Due to the nature of the task neither double nor single blinding will be possible.

question.value:
Two designs will be applied. First, a repeated measures design will be applied in which scores in the swearing and non-swearing conditions will be compared using paired samples t-tests. The dependent variables will be scores from the plank task (time position can be maintained in seconds up to a maximum of 300), the push up task (total number of repetitions completed in five minutes or until the participant stops), the wall sit task (time position can be maintained in seconds up to a maximum of 300s), heart rate during each task (BPM), heart rate variability during each task (SDPP), systolic and diastolic blood pressure during each task (mgHg), the Borg Perceived Pain scale score and the Engeser (2016) Flow Short Scale score completed after all three physical tasks have been undertaken.

Second, a 2 × 2 mixed design will be applied with the within-subjects factor swearing (swearing vs. non-swearing) and the between-subjects factor condition order (swearing first vs. non-swearing first) for the dependent variables plank score, push ups score and wall sit score and for any of the other dependent variables indicated to be significantly different across the swearing and non-swearing conditions. This will be to verify the absence of carryover effects arising from the repeated measures design.

q9.value: Participants will be randomized to exercise order and swearing condition first / second. This will be achieved using the MS Excel random number generator function and determined prior to the commencement of data collection.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: This version was created as the location of data collection was extended to a UK University. At this juncture we have N=30 data sets collected in Brooklyn. We have not yet handled or summarised the data in any way. Data analysis has not commenced.

question.value:
Participant Population

Participant population will include currently enrolled students or faculty/staff ages 18-35 years) of a North-Eastern private college in the United States and a UK University. The current protocol will exclude any participants who have a history of chronic illness, including but not limited to cardiovascular diseases, neuromuscular disorder, and orthopedic injury or medication that would preclude participation in this study. In addition, participants with a low back injury or low back pain (within 6 months) will be excluded from the study.

Participants will be instructed to wear appropriate exercise attire. Participants will be required to complete the study between 9:00AM and 5:00PM on weekdays. The study will commence in the Fall of 2017.

Recruitment

Initial contact and participant selection will be made via flyers and through graduate students working with the principal investigators. 

R1. The research will be described in recruitment materials as a study assessing vocalisation techniques in the context of exercise and well being, with clear guidance that some participants will be asked to swear out loud as part of the procedure. 

R2. Participants will be instructed to wear appropriate exercise attire for all sessions (e.g., shorts, t-shirt, jog bra) and will be required to complete the study between 9:00 AM and 5:00 PM on weekdays.

R3. Participants will be asked to complete a health status questionnaire as part of the 
screening for eligibility process. 

Procedure

A test schedule document will summarize the steps to be followed, provide space to record data and it will have several versions that will facilitate randomization of the order in which the exercises are to be completed in the circuit for each participant AND condition order for each participant (i.e., swearing vs. neutral word).

P1. Upon entering the laboratory, all participants will be briefed on the procedures related to the study and will complete an informed consent, which will be witnessed and formally recorded. Once the consent has been signed and witnessed, participants will be asked if they have any questions regarding the study.

P2. Participants will be instructed on how to position a chest strap of a heart rate monitor beneath their clothing. They will then be instructed that they will be able to wear a t-shirt over the chest strap for the duration of the study. If necessary, they will be told to go to the restroom to put on the strap and monitor.

P3. Resting Heart Rate - After returning to the lab, participants will be asked to sit quietly in a chair for 5 mins 30 secs. Resting heart rate and blood pressure will be monitored during the final 30 seconds of the 5-minute rest period. Data will be recorded on the data input sheet.

P4. After this recording, participants will be asked to nominate a swear word (“A word that you might say if you accidentally injured yourself”) and a neutral word (“A word that you might use to describe a table”). These words will be recorded by the investigator.

P5. Participants will practice the three exercises to be performed with guidance and feedback from the tester until they understand what is entailed and can do each exercise without input from the tester.

P6. Participants will be asked to repeat their first word (i.e., swearing vs. neutral word) for 20s while sitting before being directed to complete one circuit comprising the three exercises in which the word is repeated every 3s for each exercise. The tester will record the outputs for each exercise (time position held for Plank & Wall Sit; number of repetitions completed for Push Ups.)

P7. Participants will take a 2 minute recovery between each exercise. Heart rate and blood pressure will also be recorded during the recovery period. During this rest period they will be asked to complete the Borg Perceived Pain scale and the Engeser (2016) Flow Short Scale 10Qs.

P8. Participants will be given 5 minutes to rest between circuits of exercise and then the protocol will be repeated.

P9. Participants will be randomized to exercise order and swearing condition. and will repeat Steps P6 & P7 for the other word, depending on condition order.

P10. Participants have the opportunity to retire to a rest room to remove the chest strap. Participants will be thanked and debriefed including the opportunity to ask questions.

Exercise Procedure and Scoring

Plank

The plank test measures core endurance. The aim of the plank assessment is to have the participant hold an elevated position for as long as possible. The plank begins with the upper body supported off the ground by the elbows and forearms, and the legs straight with the weight taken by the toes. The hip is lifted off the floor creating a straight line from head to toe. As soon as the subject is in the correct position, the stopwatch is started. The test is over when the subject is unable to hold the back straight and the hip is lowered.

Score will be determined by the total time completed at the first attempt. In the case of a non-fatiguing participant, an upper time limit of 5 minutes will be employed. No credit will be awarded should participants attempt to repeat the procedure within the time limit. Equipment needed to complete this task is a flat clean surface, a floor mat, and a stopwatch.

Push Up

The push-up (also called the press up) measures upper body strength and endurance. The push up test begins with the participant’s hands and toes touching the floor, the body and legs are in a straight line, feet slightly apart, the arms at shoulder width apart, extended and at a right angle to the body. Keeping the back and knees straight, the participant will be instructed to lower the body to a 4-inch foam block that is placed under the chest (located at the costal arch and above the Zyphoid bone). The participant will be instructed to lower their body until they slightly compress the foam cube, and until the arms are at least parallel to the floor, then they will push up again to the original position.

The back must be kept straight, and in each extension up, the elbows should lock. Resting is allowed, though only in the up (starting) position. This action will be repeated, and the test will continue until the participant can no longer keep their initial form, until exhaustion, or when they request to stop.

Score will be determined by the total number of repetitions completed at the first attempt. In the case of a non-fatiguing participant, an upper time limit of 5 minutes will be employed. No credit will be awarded should participants attempt to repeat the procedure within the time limit. Equipment needed to complete this task includes a flat clean surface, a 4-inch yoga block, and a floor mat.

Wall Sit

The wall sit measures the strength endurance of the lower body, particularly the quadriceps. To begin the test, participants will be instructed to stand comfortably with feet approximately shoulder width apart, with their back against a smooth vertical wall. The feet will be placed about 6 inches apart, 1.5 to 2 feet away from the wall, and parallel to one another. Participants will then slowly slide themselves down the wall to assume a position where both knees and hips are at a 90° angle.

Score is determined by the total time that the position was held for at the first attempt. In the case of a non-fatiguing participant, an upper time limit of 5 minutes will be employed. No credit will be awarded should participants attempt to repeat the procedure within the time limit. Equipment needed to complete this task includes a smooth wall, and a stopwatch.

q13.value: The sample size will be N = 120.

q14.value: Power calculations have been based on effect sizes for the variable heart rate variability based on data from the previous study (Stephens, Spierer and Katehis, in submission). Previously we found a modest effect size for this variable of dz = 0.29. Comparing means across related groups, for two-tailed alpha = 0.05, power = 0.80 and dz = 0.30 we calculate an overall minimum sample size of N = 90 is required. We plan to recruit 120 participants in order to mitigate against missing data, data exclusion during analysis (such as outliers) and / or participants electing not to continue with the full procedure.

question.value: The manipulated variable will be swearing vs. non-swearing. Participants will be asked to nominate a swear word (“A word that you might say if you accidentally injured yourself”) and a neutral word (“A word that you might use to describe a table”). These words will be recorded by the investigator.

The dependent variables will be scores from the plank task (time position can be maintained in seconds up to a maximum of 300), the push up task (total number of repetitions completed in five minutes or until the participant stops), the wall sit task (time position can be maintained in seconds up to a maximum of 300s), heart rate during each task (BPM), heart rate variability during each task (SDPP), systolic and diastolic blood pressure during each task (mgHg), the Borg Perceived Pain scale score and the Engeser (2016) Flow Short Scale score completed after all three physical tasks have been undertaken. Please note that we are discounting employing sex as a variable because, although women’s and men’s physical performance capabilities differ, we do not expect any specific effect of swearing.

Differences between the dependent variables listed above will be compared across the swearing and non- swearing conditions using a series of t-tests, applying a two-tailed alpha of 0.05. 
	
An additional series of 2 × 2 mixed design ANOVAs will be applied with the within-subjects factor swearing (swearing vs. non-swearing) and the between-subjects factor condition order (swearing first vs. non-swearing first) for the dependent variables plank score, push ups score and wall sit score and for any of the other dependent variables indicated to be significantly different across the swearing and non-swearing conditions. This will be to verify the absence of carryover effects arising from the repeated measures design, or, should carryover effects be present, to enable them to be taken into account when interpreting the findings.

q20.value:
Dependent variables will be checked for normality by a visual inspection of Box and Whisker plots and by calculating skew and kurtosis coefficients. Please note that we are using the SPSS definition of an outlier as a value that is more than 1.5 times above or below the interquartile range (also known as the Tukey Fences method of identifying outliers). 
	
First, outliers identified in Box and Whisker plots will be removed and Box and Whisker plots will be replotted and rechecked, iteratively. If outliers can be removed without replacement by new outliers with wastage of ten or fewer participants, then next skew and kurtosis coefficients will be checked. The data will be declared normal provided these fall within the range -2.0 to 2.0. Should the above not succeed in producing a normal distribution for a DV then a transform will be applied and the process will be repeated for the transformed data. Transforms will be applied in the order: log10, square root, square, inverse. If normal data cannot be achieved after following these steps then we will run the planned analyses using both parametric and the equivalent non-parametric tests. If the two sets of analyses provide the same results then only the parametric analyses will be reported with an explanation that non-parametric equivalent analyses produced the same result. Otherwise the non-parametric analyses will be reported.

q21.value:
T-tests: alpha <0.05 (two-tailed)
ANOVA: alpha <0.05

As these analyses are being carried out according to an a priori plan, and as each DV represents a separate theoretical family, there will be no further control for type I error.

q22.value:
Outliers identified in Box and Whisker plots will be removed and Box and Whisker plots will be rechecked iteratively. If outliers can be removed and not replaced by new outliers with wastage of ten or fewer participants, then this will be done. Otherwise the data will be transformed (see above) and the process of checking for outliers will be repeated. 
	
Participants that are unable to carry out the requested exercises (plank, push ups, sit ups) to a minimum standard (hold plank/ wall sit for 5s; do at least 1 push up) will be excluded from the analysis on the grounds that they may have misunderstood the instructions and so not be performing within the required parameters.

registration_responses.q1: Effect of swearing on strength and power performance – a follow up study
registration_responses.q3:
We have previously shown that repeating a swear word can improve performance of anaerobic and isometric exercise compared with a control condition of repeating a neutral word (Stephens, Spierer and Katehis, in submission). However, the mechanism of effect was unclear because anticipated signs of autonomic arousal in the swearing conditions were not present. The present study aims to further investigate in this area by (i) extending investigation of the range of physical tasks that may be improved by swearing to endurance tasks; (ii) re-appraising autonomic arousal in the context of swearing and physical performance; and (iii) assessing other potential mechanisms, specifically, pain and psychological flow. 

1.	Does repeating a swear word improve performance of physical endurance tasks?
2.	Mechanism#1 Does repeating a swear word in the context of physical endurance produce increases in autonomic arousal relative to repeating a neutral word?
3.	Mechanism#2 Does repeating a swear word in the context of physical endurance produce reduced feelings of pain associated with the exercise relative to repeating a neutral word?
4.	Mechanism#3 Does swearing increase feelings of flow during the physical endurance tasks relative to repeating a neutral word?

registration_responses.q14: Power calculations have been based on effect sizes for the variable heart rate variability based on data from the previous study (Stephens, Spierer and Katehis, in submission). Previously we found a modest effect size for this variable of dz = 0.29. Comparing means across related groups, for two-tailed alpha = 0.05, power = 0.80 and dz = 0.30 we calculate an overall minimum sample size of N = 90 is required. We plan to recruit 120 participants in order to mitigate against missing data, data exclusion during analysis (such as outliers) and / or participants electing not to continue with the full procedure.
registration_responses.q20:
Dependent variables will be checked for normality by a visual inspection of Box and Whisker plots and by calculating skew and kurtosis coefficients. Please note that we are using the SPSS definition of an outlier as a value that is more than 1.5 times above or below the interquartile range (also known as the Tukey Fences method of identifying outliers). 
	
First, outliers identified in Box and Whisker plots will be removed and Box and Whisker plots will be replotted and rechecked, iteratively. If outliers can be removed without replacement by new outliers with wastage of ten or fewer participants, then next skew and kurtosis coefficients will be checked. The data will be declared normal provided these fall within the range -2.0 to 2.0. Should the above not succeed in producing a normal distribution for a DV then a transform will be applied and the process will be repeated for the transformed data. Transforms will be applied in the order: log10, square root, square, inverse. If normal data cannot be achieved after following these steps then we will run the planned analyses using both parametric and the equivalent non-parametric tests. If the two sets of analyses provide the same results then only the parametric analyses will be reported with an explanation that non-parametric equivalent analyses produced the same result. Otherwise the non-parametric analyses will be reported.
registration_responses.q21:
T-tests: alpha <0.05 (two-tailed)
ANOVA: alpha <0.05

As these analyses are being carried out according to an a priori plan, and as each DV represents a separate theoretical family, there will be no further control for type I error.

registration_responses.q8.question:
Two designs will be applied. First, a repeated measures design will be applied in which scores in the swearing and non-swearing conditions will be compared using paired samples t-tests. The dependent variables will be scores from the plank task (time position can be maintained in seconds up to a maximum of 300), the push up task (total number of repetitions completed in five minutes or until the participant stops), the wall sit task (time position can be maintained in seconds up to a maximum of 300s), heart rate during each task (BPM), heart rate variability during each task (SDPP), systolic and diastolic blood pressure during each task (mgHg), the Borg Perceived Pain scale score and the Engeser (2016) Flow Short Scale score completed after all three physical tasks have been undertaken.

Second, a 2 × 2 mixed design will be applied with the within-subjects factor swearing (swearing vs. non-swearing) and the between-subjects factor condition order (swearing first vs. non-swearing first) for the dependent variables plank score, push ups score and wall sit score and for any of the other dependent variables indicated to be significantly different across the swearing and non-swearing conditions. This will be to verify the absence of carryover effects arising from the repeated measures design.
registration_responses.q12.question:
Participant Population

Participant population will include currently enrolled students or faculty/staff ages 18-35 years) of a North-Eastern private college in the United States and a UK University. The current protocol will exclude any participants who have a history of chronic illness, including but not limited to cardiovascular diseases, neuromuscular disorder, and orthopedic injury or medication that would preclude participation in this study. In addition, participants with a low back injury or low back pain (within 6 months) will be excluded from the study.

Participants will be instructed to wear appropriate exercise attire. Participants will be required to complete the study between 9:00AM and 5:00PM on weekdays. The study will commence in the Fall of 2017.

Recruitment

Initial contact and participant selection will be made via flyers and through graduate students working with the principal investigators. 

R1. The research will be described in recruitment materials as a study assessing vocalisation techniques in the context of exercise and well being, with clear guidance that some participants will be asked to swear out loud as part of the procedure. 

R2. Participants will be instructed to wear appropriate exercise attire for all sessions (e.g., shorts, t-shirt, jog bra) and will be required to complete the study between 9:00 AM and 5:00 PM on weekdays.

R3. Participants will be asked to complete a health status questionnaire as part of the 
screening for eligibility process. 

Procedure

A test schedule document will summarize the steps to be followed, provide space to record data and it will have several versions that will facilitate randomization of the order in which the exercises are to be completed in the circuit for each participant AND condition order for each participant (i.e., swearing vs. neutral word).

P1. Upon entering the laboratory, all participants will be briefed on the procedures related to the study and will complete an informed consent, which will be witnessed and formally recorded. Once the consent has been signed and witnessed, participants will be asked if they have any questions regarding the study.

P2. Participants will be instructed on how to position a chest strap of a heart rate monitor beneath their clothing. They will then be instructed that they will be able to wear a t-shirt over the chest strap for the duration of the study. If necessary, they will be told to go to the restroom to put on the strap and monitor.

P3. Resting Heart Rate - After returning to the lab, participants will be asked to sit quietly in a chair for 5 mins 30 secs. Resting heart rate and blood pressure will be monitored during the final 30 seconds of the 5-minute rest period. Data will be recorded on the data input sheet.

P4. After this recording, participants will be asked to nominate a swear word (“A word that you might say if you accidentally injured yourself”) and a neutral word (“A word that you might use to describe a table”). These words will be recorded by the investigator.

P5. Participants will practice the three exercises to be performed with guidance and feedback from the tester until they understand what is entailed and can do each exercise without input from the tester.

P6. Participants will be asked to repeat their first word (i.e., swearing vs. neutral word) for 20s while sitting before being directed to complete one circuit comprising the three exercises in which the word is repeated every 3s for each exercise. The tester will record the outputs for each exercise (time position held for Plank & Wall Sit; number of repetitions completed for Push Ups.)

P7. Participants will take a 2 minute recovery between each exercise. Heart rate and blood pressure will also be recorded during the recovery period. During this rest period they will be asked to complete the Borg Perceived Pain scale and the Engeser (2016) Flow Short Scale 10Qs.

P8. Participants will be given 5 minutes to rest between circuits of exercise and then the protocol will be repeated.

P9. Participants will be randomized to exercise order and swearing condition. and will repeat Steps P6 & P7 for the other word, depending on condition order.

P10. Participants have the opportunity to retire to a rest room to remove the chest strap. Participants will be thanked and debriefed including the opportunity to ask questions.

Exercise Procedure and Scoring

Plank

The plank test measures core endurance. The aim of the plank assessment is to have the participant hold an elevated position for as long as possible. The plank begins with the upper body supported off the ground by the elbows and forearms, and the legs straight with the weight taken by the toes. The hip is lifted off the floor creating a straight line from head to toe. As soon as the subject is in the correct position, the stopwatch is started. The test is over when the subject is unable to hold the back straight and the hip is lowered.

Score will be determined by the total time completed at the first attempt. In the case of a non-fatiguing participant, an upper time limit of 5 minutes will be employed. No credit will be awarded should participants attempt to repeat the procedure within the time limit. Equipment needed to complete this task is a flat clean surface, a floor mat, and a stopwatch.

Push Up

The push-up (also called the press up) measures upper body strength and endurance. The push up test begins with the participant’s hands and toes touching the floor, the body and legs are in a straight line, feet slightly apart, the arms at shoulder width apart, extended and at a right angle to the body. Keeping the back and knees straight, the participant will be instructed to lower the body to a 4-inch foam block that is placed under the chest (located at the costal arch and above the Zyphoid bone). The participant will be instructed to lower their body until they slightly compress the foam cube, and until the arms are at least parallel to the floor, then they will push up again to the original position.

The back must be kept straight, and in each extension up, the elbows should lock. Resting is allowed, though only in the up (starting) position. This action will be repeated, and the test will continue until the participant can no longer keep their initial form, until exhaustion, or when they request to stop.

Score will be determined by the total number of repetitions completed at the first attempt. In the case of a non-fatiguing participant, an upper time limit of 5 minutes will be employed. No credit will be awarded should participants attempt to repeat the procedure within the time limit. Equipment needed to complete this task includes a flat clean surface, a 4-inch yoga block, and a floor mat.

Wall Sit

The wall sit measures the strength endurance of the lower body, particularly the quadriceps. To begin the test, participants will be instructed to stand comfortably with feet approximately shoulder width apart, with their back against a smooth vertical wall. The feet will be placed about 6 inches apart, 1.5 to 2 feet away from the wall, and parallel to one another. Participants will then slowly slide themselves down the wall to assume a position where both knees and hips are at a 90° angle.

Score is determined by the total time that the position was held for at the first attempt. In the case of a non-fatiguing participant, an upper time limit of 5 minutes will be employed. No credit will be awarded should participants attempt to repeat the procedure within the time limit. Equipment needed to complete this task includes a smooth wall, and a stopwatch.
registration_responses.q16.question: The manipulated variable will be swearing vs. non-swearing. Participants will be asked to nominate a swear word (“A word that you might say if you accidentally injured yourself”) and a neutral word (“A word that you might use to describe a table”). These words will be recorded by the investigator.
registration_responses.q17.question: The dependent variables will be scores from the plank task (time position can be maintained in seconds up to a maximum of 300), the push up task (total number of repetitions completed in five minutes or until the participant stops), the wall sit task (time position can be maintained in seconds up to a maximum of 300s), heart rate during each task (BPM), heart rate variability during each task (SDPP), systolic and diastolic blood pressure during each task (mgHg), the Borg Perceived Pain scale score and the Engeser (2016) Flow Short Scale score completed after all three physical tasks have been undertaken. Please note that we are discounting employing sex as a variable because, although women’s and men’s physical performance capabilities differ, we do not expect any specific effect of swearing.
registration_responses.q18.question: N/A
registration_responses.q19.question:
Differences between the dependent variables listed above will be compared across the swearing and non- swearing conditions using a series of t-tests, applying a two-tailed alpha of 0.05. 
	
An additional series of 2 × 2 mixed design ANOVAs will be applied with the within-subjects factor swearing (swearing vs. non-swearing) and the between-subjects factor condition order (swearing first vs. non-swearing first) for the dependent variables plank score, push ups score and wall sit score and for any of the other dependent variables indicated to be significantly different across the swearing and non-swearing conditions. This will be to verify the absence of carryover effects arising from the repeated measures design, or, should carryover effects be present, to enable them to be taken into account when interpreting the findings.

attributes.title: Sleep-Impulsivity-Behaviour Project
attributes.description: Self-injurious behaviour, such as biting, scratching and head banging, occurs at very high rates in children with autism and intellectual disability (ID). As many as 1 in 2 children with autism and ID will self-injure, and in most cases these behaviours persist beyond childhood. Unfortunately, self-injurious behaviour is a primary cause of family stress, and often leads to placement breakdown resulting in children requiring specialist residential placements away from the family home. The Sleep-Impulsivity-Behaviour (SIB) Study investigates two potential causes or drivers of self-injurious behaviour. First, we examine a fundamental brain-based capacity. Our work suggests that children who self-injure have problems stopping and starting their own behaviour; this brain-based capacity is called inhibition. Second, we investigate whether poor sleep makes self-injurious behaviour more likely. We are particularly interested in whether specific sleep difficulties, for example problems with falling asleep, problems with staying asleep, or problems with sleeping at the wrong time in a 24-hour cycle, lead to more frequent and more severe self-injury. To complete the SIB Study, we will bring together these two strands of work. In children without autism and ID, sleep is also known to influence inhibition. Therefore, we think that inhibition may explain part of the relationship between poor sleep and self-injurious behaviour. We will test this idea by running a plan to improve children’s sleep. We will measure inhibition and self-injurious behaviour to see if improvements in inhibition explain some of the changes in self-injury. Together, all three of these pieces of work will show whether poor inhibition and poor sleep cause self-injurious behaviour in children with autism and ID. Positive findings will inform interventions for self-injurious behaviour, with sleep and inhibition as new, preventative intervention targets.

q1.value: The role of impulsivity in self-injurious behaviour

q2.value: Georgie Agar, Chloe Brown, Andrew Bagshaw, Rory Thomas Devine, Frank Symons, Caroline Richards

q3.value: Self-injurious behaviour, such as biting, scratching and head banging, occurs at very high rates in children with autism and intellectual disability (ID). As many as 1 in 2 children with autism and ID will self-injure, and in most cases these behaviours persist beyond childhood. Unfortunately, self-injurious behaviour is a primary cause of family stress, and often leads to placement breakdown resulting in children requiring specialist residential placements away from the family home. The Sleep-Impulsivity-Behaviour (SIB) Study investigates two potential causes or drivers of self-injurious behaviour. First, we examine a fundamental brain-based capacity. Our work suggests that children who self-injure have problems stopping and starting their own behaviour; this brain-based capacity is called inhibition.

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1: We predict that children who show self-injury will have significantly poorer performance on measures of response inhibition compared with children without self-injury

Hypothesis 2: We predict that within the self-injury group, children with more severe and frequent self-injury will have significantly poorer performance on measures of conflict inhibition

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Between-group test of executive functioning (i.e., response inhibition, conflict inhibition, and working memory) in participants who do and do not show self-injury.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Children will be recruited via existing databases held by the authors and through schools for children with autism/ID. Recruitment feasibility is supported by an extensive network of SIB Study partner organisations including local and national NHS Trusts and networks, national charities, schools and research centres. The study will also be advertised via digital platforms (e.g. social media, websites). Parents/carers answering this advertisement will be self-selected and therefore will not be identified beforehand. However digital advertisement will be directed at platforms where parents/carers of eligible participants are known to visit e.g. support groups, autism charity websites. 

In all recruitment pathways (except social media and advertisements where parents/carers only view the advertisement/flyer) parents/carers of potential participants will receive a recruitment pack containing a flyer advertising the study, an expression of interest postcard and a pre-paid envelope. Parents/carers will be instructed to either contact the research team or return the expression of interest postcard in the pre-paid envelope. Those recruited via digital platforms will only see the flyer so will be instructed to contact the research team directly.

Following receipt of an expression of interest postcard or direct contact from a family, parents/carers will then be contacted via telephone by a member of the research team Birmingham to confirm eligibility for the study using the contact information that they have provided. 

Children are eligible if they meet the following criteria:
•	are aged 4 years - 15 years 9 months
•	live in the UK
•	have been diagnosed with intellectual disability
•	have been diagnosed with autism, or autism diagnosis is highly suspected by the PI and the research team
•	have not been diagnosed with a genetic syndrome
•	have a parent/carer with the ability to provide informed consent, complete consent forms, questionnaires and an interview

We will not recruit children who:
•	are outside the ages of 4 years -15 years 9 months
•	live outside of the UK
•	do not have an intellectual disability
•	do not have a diagnosis, or suspected diagnosis, of autism
•	have been diagnosed with a genetic syndrome
•	do not have a parent/carer with the ability to provide informed consent, complete consent forms, questionnaires and an interview

Travel expenses will be paid for any visits made by participants that are related to study activities. This will be a cash or voucher reimbursement paid directly to the parent/carer of the participant. A small gift as compensation for the participant/family will be presented upon completion of the assessments.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 79 children who show self-injury and 79 children who do not. We will attempt to recruit 174 children, to allow for incomplete assessments. Sample sizes may vary based upon logistical constraints of the project. Current recruitment range estimates are based upon analysis that suggested participant numbers would be sufficient to detect a medium effect size.

question.value:
We will measure the severity of participants’ autism characteristics using the Autism Diagnostic Observation Schedule – II. Ability is assessed through a brief battery of tools to capture the highly variable profile of verbal/non-verbal IQ, performance IQ and adaptive functioning seen in children with ID. The Vineland Adaptive Behavior Scales (VABS) parent interview is administered to measure adaptive behaviour, the British Picture Vocabulary Scales (BPVS) to measure receptive language and non-verbal index scales from the Wechsler Preschool and Primary Scale of Intelligence – Fourth Edition (WPPSI - IV) or Weschler Intelligence Scale for Children (WISC-V) to measure non-verbal IQ. If children are not able to complete the WPPSI or WISC, tasks from the visual reception and fine motor subscales of the Mullen Scales of Early Learning will be used.

The Challenging Behaviour Questionnaire details the presence, topography and severity of self-injury. Developmentally appropriate tasks will also be selected to measure the three key constructs of executive function – working memory (e.g. multi-location search), response inhibition (e.g. The Prohibition Task) and conflict inhibition (e.g. categorization /reverse categorization).

To test Hypothesis 1, we will use a between-groups t-test or non-parametric equivalent to compare test performance on measures of inhibition between children who do and do not show self-injury. Regression analyses will also be conducted with each EF task as the outcome. IQ, verbal ability, ADOS severity and self-injury/non-self injury will be used as predictors.

To test Hypothesis 2 we will correlate EF performance with severity and frequency of self-injury. For example, correlate latency to touch the item in The Prohibition Task with frequency of self-injury according to Item 1.4 of the CBQ.

attributes.title: The Negative Effects of a Healthy Context on Victims’ Adjustment: Number of Friends as a Moderator

q1.value: The Negative Effects of a Healthy Context on Victims’ Adjustment: Number of Friends, Mutual Friendships and Proximity with Friends as Moderators

q2.value: Saranya Mukherjee, Sabine Stoltz, Tessa Lansu

q3.value: Although there is evidence that anti-bullying interventions help in reducing the number of victims in a classroom and creates a healthy context, it also increases adjustment problems for victims who continue to be victimised. We will measure whether a healthy context negatively predicts the adjustment problems for stable victims and if the number of friends, mutual friendships and physical proximity with friends play a moderating role.

q4.value:
1. Reduction in the number of victims (healthy context) negatively predicts adjustment outcomes such as depression and social anxiety for those who are still victimized at T2
 2. The relationship between a healthy context and adjustment outcomes is worse for stable victims with lesser friends, lesser mutual friends and lesser physical proximity with friends at T2

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: We have a mixed design with two groups - intervention group and control group with multiple levels for schools, classrooms and interventions.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

q11.value: I do not have access to the data yet.

question.value: We use data that has already been collected. Data were collected from schools twice; once at the beginning of the school year before the start of the interventions (T1; September-October 2016) and once at the end of the school year at intervention termination (T2; June-July 2017). For the purpose of the current study, we used data from T1 and T2 to compare the differences between victims at two time points and compare the effects over time.

q13.value: The sample consists around 700 stable victims.

q14.value: I choose to conduct my analysis only on stable victims because I measure their adjustment problems at the two time points to compare the effectiveness of the intervention.

question.value: Friendship was measured using the Affective sociometry: Peer personal assessments. It included items such as ‘Which classmates are your bestfriends?’ and ‘Are there children from other classes who are your best friends?’. The questions were rated between 0-1(0 = no and 1 = yes). Number of friends and mutual friendships was assessed using the scale by checking the number of friends the stable victim indicated and if they were also nominated by the same peers. Self-reported victimization was measured using the Revised Olweus Bully/Victim questionnaire. It included the global item, ‘‘How often have you been bullied at school in the last couple of months?’’ Answers were given on a 5-point scale: 0 = not at all, 1 = once or twice, 2 = two or three times a month, 3 = once a week, 4 = several times a week. Children who reported being bullied at least two or three times a month were classified as victims. Stable victims were those who reported being bullied at least two or three times a month at both T1 and T2. Social anxiety was measured using the Social Phobia Screening Questionnaire (modified) with items such as ‘I find it scary to raise my hand during class’ and ‘I find it scary to talk to someone I don't know’. The questions were rated on a scale of 1-5 (1 = never and 5 = always). Depression was measured using the Major Depression Disorder Scale with nine items such as ‘I’m having trouble sleeping’ and ‘I’m very tired’. The questions were rated on a scale of 1-4 (1 = never and 4 = always). The dependent variables include social anxiety and depression. The independent variable is healthy context measured by a reduction in the number of victims across two time points. Age, Gender and Intervention Effect will be included as control variables.

The data will be analyzed using multi-level modeling. We will distinguish two models, in the first model, adjustment problems (social anxiety and depression) are the dependent variables and reduction in the number of victims (healthy context) is the independent variable. The second model will have three parts, in the first part the interaction between the healthy context and the number of friends will be the predictor of adjustment problems, the interaction between the healthy context and mutual friendships will be the predictor of adjustment problems in the second part and in the final part the interaction between the healthy context and physical proximity with friends will be the predictor of adjustment problems. All the three parts of the second model will be compared to the first one to measure whether any or all of these factors play a moderating role in the relationship between a healthy context and adjustment problems of a stable victim.

q23.value: The ‘BaylorEdPsych’ which provides the Little’s MCAR test will be used to measure whether data is missing at random or not. Full Information Maximum Likelihood (FIML) will be used to deal with missing data.

q24.value: Basic descriptives such as univariate distributions, bivariate associations, skewness, kurtosis, and missing values will be checked. The ‘VIM’ package will be used to describe prevalence, patterns, and visualizations of observed and missing data. Multivariate normality and outliers will be tested using the ‘MVN’ package.

registration_responses.q1: The Negative Effects of a Healthy Context on Victims’ Adjustment: Number of Friends, Mutual Friendships and Proximity with Friends as Moderators
registration_responses.q2: Saranya Mukherjee, Sabine Stoltz, Tessa Lansu
registration_responses.q3: Although there is evidence that anti-bullying interventions help in reducing the number of victims in a classroom and creates a healthy context, it also increases adjustment problems for victims who continue to be victimised. We will measure whether a healthy context negatively predicts the adjustment problems for stable victims and if the number of friends, mutual friendships and physical proximity with friends play a moderating role.
registration_responses.q4:
1. Reduction in the number of victims (healthy context) negatively predicts adjustment outcomes such as depression and social anxiety for those who are still victimized at T2
 2. The relationship between a healthy context and adjustment outcomes is worse for stable victims with lesser friends, lesser mutual friends and lesser physical proximity with friends at T2

registration_responses.q12.question: We use data that has already been collected. Data were collected from schools twice; once at the beginning of the school year before the start of the interventions (T1; September-October 2016) and once at the end of the school year at intervention termination (T2; June-July 2017). For the purpose of the current study, we used data from T1 and T2 to compare the differences between victims at two time points and compare the effects over time.
